column4: hey how on earth do i move a file into /etc/init.d ??? says im not allowed to?
whats the command in terminal to do this?>
yup, got the sessions sorted mate
lol
see, im trying to portforward azureus
but i gotta move this iptable-azureus file into etc/init.d
but i dont know how to do it command line
when i try to do it the GUI way, it wont let me
mmmmmm
port forward?
why?

you keep saying that, but I don't think it means what you think it means.  To put it another way, I installed azureus and only port forwarded my router.  Since Ubuntu, by default, had everything else open for me as I could see with sudo iptables -L

I don't think adding iptable rules is going to change that though.  I think the problem lies elsewhere.  I personally have noticed that sometimes azureus will just choke and tell me I'm firewalled when it isn't and then I'll restart and it will be fine
restart azureus that is.  I'm looking gimme a sec
do me a favor and type sudo iptables all and look at the default policy for each of the three things.  I'm just curious because I actually feel that the guide you are looking at is wrong....
I meant sudo iptables -L  sorry about that
yeah I messed up I meant sudo iptables -L
use that site
so yeah, ok, the weird thing is that my iptables on Ubuntu were setup by default to accept everything, yours aren't.  That's why you are having problems and that's why I was confused.
ok
that makes sense then.  Haha Ok so basically whatever firewall you installed at that time changed the rules of your machine and that's why I didn't have to forward the ports but you do.
if you aren't using those firewalls anyway, I would just do sudo apt-get remove firestarter.  Then restart then do sudo iptables -L and see if it is nice and clean again
paste bin what the new sudo iptables _L did to make sure it is nice and clean.
ok, everything is open
